title: Supervision Trees + Failure-as-Learning
description: ADR 5: Replace binary pass/fail with OTP-inspired outcome taxonomy. Failure context as first-class state. Negative context injection. Restart intensity. Dual-mode autonomy. Write-layer guards.

title: Replace PipelineStatus::ImplementationFailed with outcome taxonomy

title: Deferred tasks return to queue with context attached

title: Time-windowed failure detection (restart intensity)

title: Escalation path: agent -> pipeline -> orchestrator -> human
description: Formalize multi-level escalation. Agent retry exhausted -> pipeline terminates with context -> orchestrator decides retry/defer/halt -> human gate if orchestrator limit reached. Each level has its own intensity budget.

title: Backoff with jitter on retryable failures
description: Exponential backoff with jitter for LLM API rate limits, transient parse errors, and network timeouts. First retry near-instant, subsequent retries grow. Prevents thundering herd on shared API endpoints.

title: Dual-mode autonomy: Maintenance vs Evolution mode
description: Maintenance Mode: max 2 files, no test mutations, auto-merge on green CI. Evolution Mode: broad scope, requires human PR review. Mode selected by task labels, priority, or explicit config. Cannot get creative growth and reliability from the same guardrails.

title: Planner enforces max files per step (blast radius control)
description: Force the Planner to chunk work: max 2 files per implementation step. If a task needs to touch 5 files, planner must generate sequential sub-steps. Probability of correct diff drops exponentially past 2 files / 150 lines.

title: File size delta checks before applying edits
description: Before applying a file write, compare old vs new size. If LLM proposes replacing a 1000-line file with 50 lines, abort. Truncation guard catches hallucinated deletions at the write layer.

title: Identifier sanitization for LLM-generated paths
description: LLMs inject colons, slashes, spaces into filenames. Sanitize all LLM-generated strings before use in file paths, branch names, URLs, or database keys. Pipeline-level guard, not agent-level.

title: Defensive JSON parsing with regex fallback

title: TQM — Self-improvement as first-degree architecture
description:
After GLITCHLAB runs a batch, it analyzes outcomes, detects failure patterns, and generates beads to fix itself. Dogfooding as architecture.

## Principle
GLITCHLAB should improve itself as it runs. When it observes patterns like decomposition loops, scope creep, or model degradation, it should create beads to fix its own bugs. TQM (Total Quality Management) as architecture.

## Insertion points
- Post-orchestrator loop: aggregate OrchestratorResult + Vec<TaskRunResult>, detect patterns, emit beads
- In orchestrator loop: between tasks, check for systemic failure patterns (restart intensity)
- In pipeline: OutcomeContext already captures structured failure data — wire it into planner prompt on retry

## Pattern types to detect
- Decomposition loops (>N decompositions in sequence)
- Scope creep (>N ScopeTooLarge obstacles)
- Model degradation (>N ParseFailure/ModelLimitation from same model)
- Stuck agents (>N max_stuck_turns hits)
- Test flakiness (>N TestFailure from same file)
- Architect rejection rate (>N% ArchitectRejected)
- Budget pressure (tasks hitting max_dollars_per_task)
- Provider failures (ExternalDependency for same service)
